‘Eksotična delovna sila‘ tudi v Sloveniji za dva evra na uro?
Niti goljufijam ni ne konca ne kraja.
05 Nov 2019, 10:12 by N. Č.



Zaradi plačila po prevoženem kilometru poskušajo vozniki manipulirati s tahografi z magneti ali vozijo na kartico voznika nekoga drugega. FOTO: Oste Bakal



V Sloveniji je morda za droben odtenek boljše kakor na vzhodu in jugu, a zakonodaja je za delavce ohlapna in neurejena. FOTO: Tadej Regent, Delo


LJUBLJANA – V Evropi (tudi v Sloveniji) primanjkuje poklicnih voznikov, zato je v krogu gospodarstvenikov in prevoznikov vzniknila ideja, da bi jih pripeljali kar s Filipinov. Status poklicnega voznika v Sloveniji je po besedah sekretarke Sindikata poklicnih voznikov Slovenije (SPVZ) Karina Ditz zelo slab, a s prihodom Filipincev bi se še bistveno poslabšal.
Nečloveško izkoriščanje
V tujini se že na veliko zaposluje 'eksotična delovna sila'. Priljubljen model je podjetje s koreninami v severozahodnih državah, ki odpre slamnata podjetja na vzhodu (Poljska, Romunija, Slovaška itd.). Voznike zaposlijo v teh slamnatih podjetjih pod pogoji in s plačami, ki veljajo tam, vozniki pa nato delajo za nemška, danska, belgijska podjetja ... Kot pojasnjuje Ditzeva, so to veliki špediterji, tudi združenja špediterjev, logistov, ki zaposlujejo na tisoče tujcev, tudi Filipincev, in jih nato »nepredstavljivo nečloveško izkoriščajo«.
Pri sosedih na tisoče Filipincev dela za dva evra na uro
Po podatkih nemških novinarjev se je prek poljskih podjetij leta 2013 zaposlilo 5000 voznikov iz držav zunaj EU, v letu 2017 jih je bilo že 65.000, samo v prvi polovici leta 2018 so jih zaposlili 53.000. Med temi je na tisoče Filipincev. Ti ljudje živijo v bednih, nečloveških razmerah. Preračunano so plačani okrog dva evra na uro.
Kot taboriščniki
»Leta dolgo ne vidijo prave postelje. Živijo in spijo v kamionih. Kadar ne vozijo, bivakirajo v kamionih na parkiriščih špediterjev, največkrat brez prh, namesto sanitarij so jim na voljo zanemarjena prenosna stranišča. Kuhajo na betonu ob kamionih in životarijo kot taboriščniki,« bedo uvožene delovne sile opisuje Ditzeva. Kot pravi, je njihov dom daleč, zato jim skoraj ne preostane drugega, kot da poskušajo preživeti v sužnjelastniškem odnosu.
V Sloveniji za odtenek manj slabo kot na jugu, na zahodu občutno boljše
Južneje so vozniki zaposleni, klavrneje se jim piše. Nič lepega se jim tako ne godi niti v Sloveniji, zato ne preseneča dejstvo, da se raje odločajo za zahodne države. »Nikjer ni idealno, je pa na severu in zahodu občutno boljše – več spoštovanja delavskih pravic, boljši oziroma bolje spoštovan pravni red, večje plače in boljša socialna varnost, pri nas v Sloveniji pa je morda za droben odtenek boljše kakor na vzhodu in jugu.«
Zakaj je status voznikov tovornjakov, kombijev, turističnih avtobusov v Sloveniji slab?
»Vozniki v Sloveniji so nezakonito plačani po prevoženem kilometru ali procentualno od vrednosti storitve prevoza, osnovna plača je nizka, večinoma minimalna ali nižja, zato so nizki nadomestila in pokojnina. Del zaslužka iz prevoženih kilometrov ali odstotkov se izplača kot regularna plača (neto 600 do 700 evrov), preostanek se prikaže v obliki fiktivnih dnevnic, realnih dnevnic za nadomestilo stroškov prehrane vozniki ne dobijo. Veliko prevoznikov ne izplača regresa, dogajajo se zamude s plačami, zgodi se, da plače sploh ni, zelo veliko je neplačanih prispevkov itd.«Tako so plačani predvsem vozniki v cestnem transportu blaga – tovornjaki, kombiji in tudi precej voznikov avtobusov v turističnem prevozu potnikov. Takšno plačilo je negativno stimulativno, saj voznika spodbuja oziroma sili, da prevozi čim več, ker je od tega odvisen zaslužek.


V Sloveniji je morda za droben odtenek boljše kakor na vzhodu in jugu, a zakonodaja je za delavce ohlapna in neurejena. FOTO: Tadej Regent, Delo

Delavce siliji k goljufiji
Za voznike veljajo stroga pravila vožnje in počitka, vse dejavnosti pa beleži tahograf (zapisuje jih na voznikovo kartico). »Ker so ta pravila tako toga in pomeni vsako odstopanje (skrajšanje počitka, podaljšanje vožnje) zelo hud prekršek, za katerega prometna kontrola voznika oglobi z zelo visokimi denarnimi globami, skušajo vozniki manipulirati s tahografi z magneti (tahograf beleži počitek, medtem ko voznik dejansko vozi) ali vozijo na kartico nekoga drugega. Velikokrat tudi prevoznik sili voznika v manipulacije s tahografom, ker ima seveda tudi on od tega korist. V bistvu še večjo kot voznik, ker pač lahko z enim kamionom opravi več voženj.«S plačilom po prevoženem kilometru prevozniki goljufajo tako voznika kot tudi državo. Del plače izplačajo kot minimalno plačo, preostanek pa kot dnevnice. »Prispevke jim delodajalec obračuna na minimalno plačo – večina voznikov v Sloveniji ima v pogodbi zapisano minimalno plačo ali še nižjo. Delodajalec tako utaji davke in prispevke državi in hkrati oškoduje delavca za prispevke za delo, realne dnevnice in nadomestilo stroškov. Država bi lahko s svojimi vzvodi pobrala vse neplačane prispevke in zagotovila plačevanje prispevkov.«
Nesposobnost ali neinteres države?
Ditzeva se ne strinja, da je srž problema v tem, da primanjkuje delovne sile, da prevoznikom primanjkuje voznikov, temveč da je vzrok pomanjkanja voznikov v neurejeni, ohlapni in nedodelani zakonodaji, nespoštovanju socialne zakonodaje, prenizkem plačilu, nezakonitem modelu plačevanja, razpasenem socialnem dampingu in nesposobnosti, morda pa tudi neinteresu naše države, da bi stvari uredila. Prihod filipinske delovne sile bi tako pomenil znižanje že tako nizkih standardov, ki veljajo za voznike v Sloveniji, zato so »v SPVS zgroženi in ogorčeni nad namero, da se sedaj k nam začnejo 'uvažati' še Filipinci«.Vozniki imajo stroga pravila vožnje in počitka:* Dnevno smejo voziti 9 ur (2 x tedensko lahko 10 ur).* Najkasneje po 4 urah in 30 minutah vožnje morajo narediti 45-minutni odmor.* Dnevno morajo neprekinjeno počivati najmanj 11 ur (3 x tedensko lahko najmanj 9 ur).* Najkasneje po 6 dnevih vožnje se morajo ustaviti za tedenski počitek, ki mora trajati 45 ur.* Lahko opravijo skrajšan tedenski počitek najmanj 24 ur, vendar morajo nato manjkajočih 21 ur nadomestiti pri naslednjem dnevnem ali tedenskem počitku.* Vrstni red je redni počitek 45, skrajšanj počitek 24, redni počitek 45 ...* Dva skrajšana počitka zaporedoma nista dovoljena.* Najkasneje konec tretjega tedna morajo nadomestiti ure skrajšanega počitka.* Vozniki v dveh zaporednih tednih ne smejo voziti več kot skupno 90 ur.

'Exotic workforce' also in Slovenia for two euros an hour?
Neither fraud nor the end nor the place.
05 Nov 2019, 10:12 by N. Č.



To pay for mileage, drivers try to manipulate tachographs with magnets or drive on someone else's driver card. PHOTO: Oste Bakal



In Slovenia, it may be a fine shade better than in the east and south, but the legislation is loose and unregulated for workers. PHOTO: Tadej Regent, Delo


LJUBLJANA - There is a shortage of professional drivers in Europe (including Slovenia), so the idea of bringing them from the Philippines came up in the circle of businessmen and carriers. The status of a professional driver in Slovenia, according to the secretary of the Union of Professional Drivers of Slovenia (SPVZ), Karina Ditz, is very bad, but with the advent of Filipinos, it would deteriorate significantly.
Inhuman exploitation
Exotic workforce is already heavily employed abroad. A popular model is a company with roots in the northwestern countries that opens straw companies in the east (Poland, Romania, Slovakia, etc.). Drivers are employed by these straw companies under the conditions and wages that apply there, and the drivers then work for German, Danish, Belgian companies ... As Ditzeva explains, these are large freight forwarders, also associations of freight forwarders, logisticians employing thousands of foreigners , including Filipinos, and are then "unthinkably inhumanly exploited".
With neighbors, thousands of Filipinos work for two euros an hour
According to German journalists, 5,000 drivers from non-EU countries were recruited through Polish companies in 2013, with 65,000 already in 2017, with 53,000 employed in the first half of 2018 alone. Thousands of Filipinos are among these. These people live in miserable, inhumane conditions. They are paid around two euros an hour.
Like campers
“They haven't seen a real bed for years. They live and sleep in trucks. When they are not driving, they are dumped in trucks in the car parks of freight forwarders, mostly without showers, and neglected portable toilets are available instead of toilets. They cook on concrete next to trucks and live like camps, ”Ditzeva describes the misery of the imported workforce. As he says, their home is far away, so they have almost nothing left but to try to survive in a slave relationship.
In Slovenia, the shade is less bad than in the south, much better in the west
The southward the drivers are employed, the more vocal they are written. They do not like anything nice in Slovenia either, so it is not surprising that they prefer Western countries. “It is not ideal anywhere, but it is much better in the north and the west - more respect for labor rights, better or better respected legal order, higher wages and better social security. In Slovenia, it may be a fine shade better than in the east and south. «
Why is the status of truck drivers, vans, buses in Slovenia poor?
»Drivers in Slovenia are illegally paid for the mileage or percentage of the value of the transport service; the basic salary is low, mostly minimal or lower, so there are low benefits and pensions. Part of the earnings from miles or percent is paid as a regular salary (net $ 600- $ 700), the rest is shown in the form of fictitious per diems, real per diems to compensate for the cost of meals for drivers are not paid. Many carriers do not pay recourse, there are wage delays, there are no wages at all, there are very many unpaid contributions, etc. "This is mainly paid for drivers in the road transport of goods - trucks, vans and also a lot of bus drivers in tourist passenger transport. . Such payment is negatively stimulating, as it encourages or forces the driver to carry as much as possible because it depends on earnings.


In Slovenia, it may be a fine shade better than in the east and south, but the legislation is loose and unregulated for workers. PHOTO: Tadej Regent, Delo

They force workers to cheat
The drivers are subject to strict driving and rest rules and all activities are recorded by the tachograph (recorded on the driver's card). "Because these rules are so rigid, and any deviation (shortening of rest, prolongation of the ride) is a very serious offense, for which the traffic control of the driver is fined with very high fines, the drivers try to manipulate the tachograph with magnets (the tachograph records rest while the driver actually drive) or drive on someone else’s card. Many times the carrier forces the driver to manipulate the tachograph, because of course he also benefits from it. Basically bigger than a driver because it can make more than one truck with one truck. ”Paying for mileage, carriers cheat both the driver and the country. They pay part of their wages as minimum wage and the rest as wages. “Their employer calculates their contributions at the minimum wage - most drivers in Slovenia have a minimum wage or even a lower wage. The employer thus evades taxes and contributions to the state while also damaging the employee for work contributions, real per diems and compensation for expenses. The state could leverage all unpaid contributions through its leverage and ensure that contributions are paid. "
Inability or disinterest of the state?
Ditzeva does not agree that the core of the problem is that there is a lack of labor, that there is a lack of drivers for the carriers, but that the lack of drivers lies in disorderly, loose and incomplete legislation, non-compliance with social legislation, underpaid payment, illegal payment model, widespread social dumping. and the inability, and perhaps the disinterest, of our country to put things right. The arrival of the Philippine workforce would mean lowering the already low standards that apply to drivers in Slovenia, so "the SSVS are appalled and indignant at the intention of now 'importing' the Filipinos as well." Rest: * They must drive for 9 hours daily (2 x weekly for 10 hours). * They must take a 45-minute break after 4 hours and 30 minutes of driving. . * They must stop for a weekly rest period of 45 hours at the latest after 6 days of driving. * They may take a short weekly rest period of at least 24 hours, but must then substitute the missing 21 hours for the next daily or weekly rest period. 45, short rest 24, regular rest 45 ... * Two short rest periods in a row are not allowed. * They must replace shortened rest hours at the end of the third week. * Do not allow drivers for two consecutive weeks. o drive more than 90 hours in total.
